description.narrative: 1) One time-series tool called 'the Viet Nam Provincial Governance and Public Administration Performance Index (PAPI)' established to measure local government performance in Viet Nam. PAPI is a rigorous policy tool that monitors and measures the performance of governance and public administration of all 63 provinces in Viet Nam based on citizens’ experiences. (PAPI is part of outputs 3.3.1 and 3.3.4 of One UN Plan) 2) Number of provinces responding to PAPI findings by seeking measures to improve their performance over time 3) Number of in-depth research conducted to bring insights into why public polices do not work and how to make them work better for the benefit of citizens

comment.narrative: 1) (Baseline 2009) No available tool that provides data to track changes in local governance and public administration reforms in Viet Nam from citizens' perspectives and experiences; no available monitoring and evaluation system to measure the effectiveness and efficiency of international development partners' support for Viet Nam in the areas of governance and public administration reforms from citizens' perspective and experience 2) (Baseline 2009) No provinces have a citizen-centric measure to monitor their performance in local governance, public administration and public service delivery 3) (Baseline 2009) No evidence-based research assessing government performance in governance and public administration reforms from citizen experiences.

1) The Viet Nam Provincial Governance and Public Administration Performance Index (PAPI) 2014 published and disseminated at the national level, involving a large diversity of stakeholders; the 2014 PAPI disseminated to provinces to show the progress of all 63 provinces in their government performance against 2011 baselines and over time in at least 7 provincial and regional workshops to disseminate PAPI 2014 convened for further policy dialogues with provinces during 2015 2) 19 provinces (cumulatively since 2011) responding to PAPI findings by introducing provincial directives or action plans to improve their performance by end 2015 3) 21 case studies (cumulatively since 2011) using PAPI data to look into the supply side’s inputs for dimensions under PAPI study completed by end 2015

1) The Viet Nam Provincial Governance and Public Administration Performance Index (PAPI) 2014 published and disseminated at the national level, involving nearly 400 participants from different government and non-government sectors. 2014 PAPI findings also disseminated through: 8 regional workshops to show the progress of all 63 provinces in their government performance against 2011 baselines and over time; 3 training workshops to guide 120 elected representatives on how to use PAPI data as evidence for policy making and oversight work. Many provincial diagnostic workshops convened to have policy dialogues with provinces during 2015. 2) As of 1 Dec 2015, at least 25 provinces (cumulatively since 2011) having responded to PAPI findings by introducing provincial directives or action plans to improve their performance. 3) 21 case studies (cumulatively since 2011) using PAPI data to look into the supply side’s inputs for dimensions under PAPI study completed by end 2015.

1) The Viet Nam Provincial Governance and Public Administration Performance Index (PAPI) 2015 published and disseminated at the national level, involving a large diversity of stakeholders; the 2015 PAPI disseminated to provinces to show the progress of all 63 provinces in their government performance against 2011 baselines and over time; at least 10 provincial and regional PAPI-related workshops convened for further policy dialogues with provinces during 2016
2) 30 provinces (cumulatively since 2011) responding to PAPI findings by introducing provincial directives or action plans to improve their performance by end 2016
3) 25 case studies (cumulatively since 2011) using PAPI data to look into the supply side’s inputs for dimensions under PAPI study completed by end 2016

1) The Viet Nam Provincial Governance and Public Administration Performance Index (PAPI) 2015 published and disseminated at the national level, involving more than 500 participants from different government and non-government sectors. 2015 PAPI findings also disseminated through: 3 large-scale regional workshops to show the progress of all 63 provinces in their government performance against 2011 baselines and over time; 12 diagnostic workshops in 12 different provinces to inform public officials, civil servants and elected representatives about their provincial performance from citizen perspective. PAPI data and findings also shared in different mainstream media channels to promote policy discussion with provinces during 2016.
2) 30 provinces (cumulatively since 2011) having responded to PAPI findings by introducing provincial directives or action plans to improve their performance.
3) 25 case studies (cumulatively since 2011) using PAPI data to look into the supply side’s inputs for dimensions under PAPI study completed.

description.narrative: 1) Gaps between Viet Nam’s Legislation on Anti-corruption and UNCAC identified. 2) Number of policy researches and dialogues providing recommendations on transparent, integrated and well-coordinated mechanisms in prevention of corruption and handling corruption cases 3) The extent to which concrete regulations on how to strengthen transparent, integrated and well-coordinated mechanisms in handling corruption cases incorporated in the new/revised laws and other legal documents (0-not at all; 1- little; 2-significantly; 3-very significantly)

comment.narrative: 1) Some gaps already identified (i) no regulations on controlling corruption/bribery in the private sector; (ii) no regulations on controlling corruption involving foreign public officials; (iii) no regulations on controlling illicit enrichment; and (iv) no regulations on controlling corruption involving legal entities. 2) There is a lack of analysis and recommendation on how to strengthen transparent, integrated and well-coordinated mechanisms in preventing and handling corruption cases 3) 0-not at all. No recommendations incorporated, as none of them were available to policy makers

1) Further gaps identified in the criminal procedures for corruption crimes 2) At least one research on mechanisms to effectively control corruption crimes: international experience and lessons learnt for Viet Nam to provide inputs for the amendment of the Criminal Procedural Code 3) 2-significant. UNDP’s recommendations incorporated in draft Criminal Procedural Code and draft Law on Anti-corruption

1) Gaps identified in following areas: (i) control of corruption in the private sector; (ii) effective sanctioning mechanisms; and (iii) mechanisms on asset recovery 2) 3 policy research papers commissioned and 3 high-level policy dialogues convened together with the Central Commission on Internal Affairs (which is under the Vietnam Communist Party Central Committee, and advisory body for the Politburo in anti-corruption) on the 3 identified regulatory areas for inputs into the revised Anti-corruption Law 3) 2-significant. UNDP’s recommendations incorporated in the draft Law on Anti-corruption (revised)

1) Gaps identified in following areas: (i) control of corruption in the private sector; (ii) effective sanctioning mechanisms; and (iii) mechanisms on asset recovery 2) Not applicable. These papers have been postpone, as the revision of the Law on Anti-corruption has been postponed by the govt. 3) Not applicable, as the revision of the Law on Anti-corruption has been postponed by the govt.

This project aims to address these threats by increasing the resilience of infrastructure to climate change in the northern mountains.

title.narrative: Signed cover page of Project Document
Midterm Review for Promoting Climate Resilient Infrastructure in Northern Mountain Provinces of Vietnam

description.narrative: Support to enhance climate resilience of rural infrastructure interventions in northern provinces of Vietnam
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division

To increase the resilience and reduce vulnerability of local critical economic infrastructure in the northern mountains areas of Vietnam to the adverse impacts of climate change and to create a policy framework conducive to promoting resilient northern mountains zone development
of public expenditure directed towards the protection of rural infrastructure following the project guidance on climate resilient infrastructure

comment.narrative: 0 funds invested
On 05 rural infrastructure projects at least 5 additional public finance invested in infrastructure resilience over and above SRID pilot demonstration

On track The vulnerability index and the hazard impact assessments will assist in the calculation of climate adaptation costs for rural infrastructure projects The economic analysis team is working on this matter to introduce the formula and a number of case studies as examples However it is difficult to apply this formula under the SRIDP subprojects because they have finished the subproject screening which requires economic analysis to be provided in advance Hence the independent Midterm review team who were mobilized by UNDPGEF in April suggest that CPMU UNDP and MARD should discuss how to utilize this result in future projects This issue might be brought to a PSC meeting which will be organized in late 2015 as expected Currently reviewing of the existing data situations documents etc has finished and the second phase to deliver recommendations is well underway
The following reports approved submitted i policy 04 reports Overview on existing policy and strategy related to rural infrastructure Report of International good practices in policy and practice for climate resilient rural infrastructure A thematic report on strengthening the resilience of rural infrastructure to climate change at international level with focus on Rural road infrastructure Rural water supply and irrigation and River protection embankment Thematic report on development of SEDP and agricultural and transportation sector plans in relation to rural infrastructure of the Northern mountain region and ii economic analysis 02 costbenefit analysis for climate proofing rural infrastructure projects Report on Measures to quantify economic damages caused by CC on rural infrastructure in Northern mountain area iii rural infrastructure engineering 5 The report on good international practice of engineering resilience in the context of rural roads irrigation network and river embankments Root cause analysis for losses and damages to the rural road infrastructure Root cause analysis for loses and damages to the irrigation and river embankment infrastructure The report on rural infrastructure vulnerability assessment to climate change for the Northern mountain provinces in Vietnam Recommendations on integration of climate change adaptation into rural road investments and Recommendations on integration of climate change into irrigation and embankment investments iv vulnerability assessment report v capacity strengthening Report on climate change impacts on poverty reduction and socioeconomic development in the northern mountain provinces Report on the need of capacity strengthening on CC adaptation of northern mountain provinces and Report on the capacity strengthening plan on CC adaptation of northern mountain provinces
A series of technical and progress meetings consultations field trips were held to improve the quality of the outputs and fasten the project progress with participation of various partners at different levels community district province and central levels Consulted institutions include i MARD Directorate of Water Resources Department of Construction Management Department of Planning Department of Science Technology and Environment Institute of Policy and Strategy for Agriculture and Rural Development Institute of Water Resources Planning Disaster Management Center New Rural Area Program Committee Department of Dyke and Flood Protection Vietnam Academy of Water Resources National Institute of Agriculture Planning and Projection Water Resources University Institute of Water Resources Planning ii MONRE Institute of Hydrology Meteorology and Climate change Vietnam Institute of Geosciences and Mineral Resources Institute of Geology and Vietnam Department of Survey and Mapping iii MOT University of Transport Transport Development and Strategy Institute iv 15 project provinces and communes

description.narrative: of vulnerability maps presented and disseminated to of Northern Mountain provinces

comment.narrative: na at project outset there is no vulnerability maps to disseminate

Detailed vulnerability maps for at least two northern mountainous provinces a map for each province with evidence that these have been presented and disseminated to at least 50 of Northern Mountain Provinces

On track Fifty percent completed Vulnerability assessment results are nearly completed The CPMU mobilized a firm and an international climate change expert in Quarter III 2014 An international climate change expert supported a national team to finalize the vulnerability assessment methodology introduced at the inception workshop November 2013 A number of meetings with different institutions individuals were held including a vulnerability assessment methodology consultation workshop in October 2014 to help finalize the methodology After data collection and analysis the consultant has submitted a complete database set and vulnerability assessment report to CPMU Results were shared with Government stakeholders from 15 Northern mountain provinces and downscaled to two piloting provinces namely Backan and Sonla This work will be further supported by the development of landslide and flashflood risk maps for the whole region and two provinces and will be completed in 2015 They are expected to provide visual vulnerability results based on different scenarios AR5 IPCC This is a valuable opportunity for GoV to place in the public domain the extent of and the spatial allocation of the likely public expenditures needed for resilience measures and considered a key impact as the baseline does not provide information on spatial variability of risk and vulnerability As such decision makers can recognize the vulnerabilities of their own provinces in comparison with other provinces They may also learn how to cope with climate change from the provinces with same situation but higher coping capacities less vulnerability On the other hand and more importantly they can use these maps as inputs for their rural infrastructurerelated decisions especially medium and longtermed planning Achievements will be shared with Northern mountain provinces through relevant trainings at the end of 2015

description.narrative: Climate Change Adaptation integrated into rural infrastructure ie transport irrigation construction and water supply strategies policies plans and regulations
of Manual on mainstreaming climate change into the design of rural infrastructure projects

comment.narrative: na at the project outset there has not been a manual to guide mainstreaming of CC into the design of rural infrastructure projects

02 manuals on mainstreaming climate change into the design of rural infrastructure projects 01 for rural roads and irrigation and 01 for embankment prepared by the project taking into consideration of results of the demonstration projects and circulated by MARD

On track The review phase indicates that although MARD has launched a lot of rural infrastructure projects applied technical codes standards regarding rural roads come from MOT However Ministry of Transport has not really touched climate change adaptation in their projects planning codes standards Hence there is a need to improve existing code standards to consider climate resilience for these infrastructures The review phase also revealed that it is not at all simple to insert project recommendations into existing codes standards of MOT since it is not only a long process but also requires interministerial discussions Despite such difficulties some findings and recommendations mentioned in the report Root cause analysis for loses and damages to the rural road infrastructure have contributed to the draft manual of rural transport roads of the MOT The contents inserted into the draft consist of i climate change impacts on rural roads ii the importance of construction of drain structures iii a number of feasible technical measures that can be applied iv a number of pavements that can increase the resilience to climate change and v the importance of bioengineering measures for slope protection This can be seen as a great effort of the project already Besides the project has had similar contribution to the upgrading of two technical standards of MARD namely slope concrete standard and dam safety standard The meetings with the two standard improvement teams have shown their high consensus in increasing the thickness of slope slabs to decrease the oxidation as consequence of extreme weather Project recommendations have been appreciated and captured in the reports of standard improvement teams Regarding the indicator of this outcome to ensure the quality of UNDPs support to MARD the MidTerm Review consultants suggest to change the indicator as of Manual on mainstreaming climate change into the design of rural infrastructure projects Presently consultant teams are working together to develop the manuals which are very coherent with each other vulnerability index and CostsBenefits calculation for instance The methodologies to develop these manuals have been discussed with CPMU and UNDP based on the orientations expectations of the participants in the policy consultation workshop dated 29th May 2015 The expectations are mainly i a policy roadmap for MARD to adapt to climate change including possible technical standards ii climate hazard risk maps and provincial planning based on these maps iii lowcost and bioengineering measures and iv related trainings It is expected that first drafts of the manuals can be available in Quarter III2015

description.narrative: of Technical papers providing guidance on mainstreaming climate change into sectorial planning related to rural infrastructure in northern areas

comment.narrative: na there has not been a guidance paper at project outset
A Technical Guidance Paper on mainstreaming climate change into provincial rural infrastructure planning prepared by the project and circulated by MARD

On track The project successfully completed a comprehensive review of relevant policies that included a series of stakeholder consultations Key findings include that most of MARD policies strategies do not take climate change into consideration and are not detailed enough for application The need to employ propoor and noregret approaches for resilience building were also clearly highlighted The New Rural Development Program Sustainable Poverty Reduction Program and provincial socioeconomic development planning processes were particularly identified as priorities for further analysis and engagement by the project
A policy consultation workshop at Thai Nguyen province on 9 September 2014 was able to solicit inputs from 11 departments institutes from MARD and MONRE and 14 DARDs The meeting further highlighted the continued interest in learning from international experience in bioengineering lowcost measures to support resilience
A comprehensive review of current rural infrastructure planning implementation and maintenance and field missions to discuss with key focal points Government officials and community representatives highlighted a number of issues regarding lowcost measures including bioengineering measures The assessment included review of experience from 27 countries from the Netherlands to Laos with legal frameworks codes and policies and implementation methods for introducing lowcost and bioengineering options
Analysis of the most recent climate change projections for Viet Nam and their potential impacts in the focus regions was also a key element of this work With regards to the analysis of key hazards for the region potential increases in intense and concentrated rainfall and associated landslide risk were highlighted as an issue in climate change projections that was particularly of concern with regards to rural infrastructure Other factors impacting current resilience of infrastructure included poor designs using unqualified materials applying unsuitable technical solutions during construction process and OM The review also recognized the clear need to integrate climate change into existing relevant codes and standards especially C677 regarding calculation of meteorological features of irrigation structures which has been issued since 1970s This implies that the vulnerability mapping under the project should take into account of abovementioned climate disasters
Key steps were also taken into initiating a review of current economic analysis practices and in starting to look at the economic consequences of climate change losses This work is likely to bolster the success of the project in suggesting appropriate methods tools and procedures for climate proofing investment decisionmaking in the NMP At a higher Provincial level it is likely that a key tool for climate change adaptation investment guidance will continue to be the application of the MCA Multi Criteria Analysis method as illustrated by the application of UNDP Teams integrated VA and Hazard models which adopt an integrated format in common with ICEM CAM methodology As an example work on the VA component has identified marked differences in Vulnerability between NMP provinces and ongoing work on Flood and Landslide Hazard risk is expected to further identify differences between provinces which can assist to pinpoint the urgency and extent of CCA interventions investments
To continue in General Comment box on Basic Data tab

description.narrative: of water resources standards and codes are informed to meet the requirements for climate resilience

comment.narrative: na there has not been any revision of water resources standards or codes
By the end of the project at least 01 set of water resources standards informed by the project guidance

On track with good progress After a lot of consultations with both central and provincial levels showed that they all are very interested in upgrading codes standards or build a new set of standards to enable the application of new technologies or lowcost measures Lack of these standards results in very timeconsuming procedures in approval of bioengineering interventions because MARD has no legal base for reference This is also why demonstration subprojects managed by ADB have encountered a lot of difficulties regarding lack of related standards for their designs Beside contributing to upgrading existing standards as mentioned in Indicator 2 of this Outcome the project is i providing detailed recommendations on a key technical standard of Vietnam in irrigation named C677 regarding calculation of meteorological features of irrigation structures and ii developing rural infrastructure engineering manuals which will provide s technical guidance for MARD to develop their own lowcost solution guidelines and then standards in near future Consultations were held with the technical staff of the Department of Science Technology and Environment MARD and Institute of Meteorology Hydrology Environment and Climate Change MONRE on updating C677 MARD is considering updating this standard in coming years and the project will provide some initial support to MARD regarding this standard as their expectations In 2015 the project expects to deliver specific recommendations by QIII and then consult again with MARD and related agencies regarding these recommendations UNDP has also been working closely with the ADB component to help create a link between target sites and Government policy development regarding lowcost measures Based on the designs site visits experience and lessons learnt and together with other feasible lessons the technical team will develop detailed technical guidance documents of lowcost measures

description.narrative: Enhanced capacity to adaptclimateproof rural infrastructure investments and provinciallocal area planning
Coverage of Climate risks and vulnerability assessment

comment.narrative: There has not been any climate vulnerability assessment implemented for rural infrastructure in Northern mountain provinces
A climate risks and vulnerability assessment for rural infrastructure done for all 15 northern provinces

On track As reported above the assessment will cover 15 project provinces including Dien Bien Lai Chau Son la Hoa Binh Vinh Phuc Phu Tho Bac Giang Bac Kan Yen Bai Lao Cai Lang Son Cao Bang Thai Nguyen Tuyen Quang and Ha Giang then downscaled to Son La and Backan After the vulnerability assessment methodology approved the contractor sent their teams to all provinces and then all districts of two demonstration provinces as named above Son La and Backan to collect secondary data and interviews for missing data OM data The types of structures under the assessment consist of i rural roads ii river embankments iii weirs iv reservoirs and v main canals that are classified as categorical and continuous The process tracks the following indicators age of works number of communes cut off from main road per year past damages number of secondary structures on road material of road embankment OM ratio of poor households proportion of minorities proportion of working age population community contribution to infrastructure number of site inspection type of construction codes followed number of times of damages number of reservoirs stopped from functioning Weightings are also laid for each kind of these indicatorsResults show a picture of Son La Backan and Ha Giang as the most vulnerable province in terms of risk These results will be further deepened with specific recommendations provided by the project in the remaining time of the year The next step will be to integrate these maps with future climate change projects

description.narrative:
Level of capacity of provincial leaders to climateproof rural infrastructure investment and planning enhanced
of technical personnel having ability to apply risk and vulnerability assessment tools and methods for rural infrastructure development planning purposes

comment.narrative:
At the project outset evaluated scores of management personnel in the 15 Northern provinces are as follows
Institutional capacity on climate change adaptation CCA 1435
Organizational and planning capacity on CCA 1715 and
Technical capacity on CCA 1785
Risk and vulnerability assessment tools and methods for rural infrastructure development planning is not yet available in Vietnam

By the end of the project capacity of provincial decision makers DARD DPI DOT DONRE to climateproof rural infrastructure investment and planning in the 15 northern mountainous provinces is at least 40 higher than the project baseline
Up to 120 technical personnel from the 15 Northern provinces trained in CCA related issues and at least 50 of them having technical capability in applying climate risks and vulnerability assessment tools and methods for rural infrastructure development planning purposes

On track with delay This activity has started slower than the others because trainings had to be developed based on project results Mobilized in Quarter II2014 the capacity strengthening expert completed a capacity strengthening assessment focusing on institutional organizational and technical capacities These results reflect the baseline of the project The assessment indicated a high level of demand for in improving the local capacity for climate change adaptation In response to this the project has decided to increase the number of training events by 40 Provincial stakeholders had a chance ot contribute to the design of the training programme through two consultation meetings Trainings will focus on 04 topics namely i Policy for climate change resilience for senior provincial officials ii Vulnerability assessment as a tool to increase climate change resilience for technical officers iii Integrating climate change resilience into annual planning and prioritization and iv Training skills about climate change adaptation for provincial officials As such the details on vulnerability assessment tools and methods for rural infrastructure planning will bee transferred in ii and iii Target trainees include leaders and technical planning staff of 04 relevant provincial departments including Department of Agriculture and Rural Development Department of Transport Department of Natural Resources and Environment and Department of Planning and Investment from 15 beneficiary provinces Trainers will be project experts or outsourced from professional agencies such as Institute of Meteorology Hydrology and Climate Change There will be a total of 12 classes for 04 mentioned topics targeted to senior and technical level staff Around 120 government personnel ware expected to be trained

description.narrative: of rural infrastructure investment plans guided as results of climate risks and vulnerability assessment regarding mainstreaming of CC

comment.narrative: na there has not been any rural infrastructure plan that is developed based on climate risk and vulnerability assessment
At least two 02 provincial plansstrategy per target province Son La and Bac Kan guided as results of the project climate risks and vulnerability assessments regarding mainstreaming of CC

Major planning decisions being modified due to vulnerability maps in 2 target provinces indicator should be changed into of rural infrastructure investment plans guided as results of climate risks and vulnerability assessment regarding mainstreaming of CC which reflects better the influences of the project on the provinces because the project can only suggest the provinces to use the outputs To date climate risk and vulnerability maps have been provided to all target provinces for use in planning Two PPCs Backan and Sonla have expressed their willingness to apply project recommendations into their investment plans A provincial strategy expert who is being under recruitment of CPMU will take this work forward
A team of provincial strategy development is under recruitment of CPMU They will be mobilized in August as expected for review of existing provincial action plans and then recommend appropriate adjustments If mapping packages can happen as expected this team can take use of the maps for their recommendation report Generally speaking this activity is on track with a risk as indicated above

Community-based participatory planning and budgeting models available in 28 provinces but not yet institutionalized. 3) 1-No progress. Available tools for poverty monitoring are income based, despite a commitment of Ministry of Labor, Invalids and Social Affairs (MOLISA) on development of a road-map for multi-dimensional poverty and emerging vulnerability monitoring and analysis.

1) 16 national targeted programs harmonized/consolidated into 2 national targeted programs; 3 education policies harmonized/consolidated into one. 2) 2-In progress. NTP- SPR 2016-2020 formulated in a consultative and harmonized process, based on the good practices and innovative models promoting resource integration, community empowerment and enhanced people's participation. 3) 3-Good progress. MDP Master Plan approved by the Prime Minister, with actions to address multidimensional needs of the poor.

1) 16 targeted programs consolidated into 2 national targeted programs (NTPs): (i) National Assembly Resolution 100/2015/QH13 on investment of two NTPs, (ii) a draft policy by Ministry of Education and Training, replacing 3 education support policies. Importantly, UNDP enabled the issuance of the Govt’s MDG accelerated targets and action plan for Ethnic Minority (MAP-EM). The Viet Nam’s MDG acceleration targets is the first in the world attempt to go beyond addressing the unfinished MDGs at the national averages to addressing the unfinished MDGs among specific population groups. This contributed to the recognition of EM groups’ lagging behind as a national priority and directed NTPs to focus on them. 2) 2-in progress. UNDP‘s work led to the adoption (i) by MPI, MOLISA, MARD and CEMA, the harmonization in the design of the NTP-SPR, with focus on improving community ownership as evidenced in the NA Resolution 100 on NTPs, and (ii) by CEMA and 8 provinces, of the social anthropological approaches in policy formulation and practice of participatory planning. These contributed to (i) improvements in the national PR program’s identifying needs of the EM and meeting these needs, (ii) proposal of the ministries for improving people participation and community empowerment toward a self-help and inclusive community development approach in the design of two NTPs 2016-2020 targeting the poorest communities. 3) 3-Good progress. Viet Nam Govt adopted multi-dimensional poverty (MDP) approach under the Prime Minister’s Decision No.1614/QĐ-Ttg. This MDP Master plan guides the national poverty reduction programming and targeting for 2016-2020. The adoption of MDP recognizes both income and non-income deprivations of the poor, including ethnic minority poor. It also means 2% of Viet Nam’s households (2.5 million people) that are not income poor but suffer from 3 or more non-income deprivations are eligible for GOVN’s poverty reduction programs and policies.

1) 16 national targeted programs harmonized/consolidated into 2 national targeted programs; 3 education policies harmonized/consolidated into one. 2) 3-Good progress. NTP- SPR 2016-2020, formulated in a consultative and harmonized process, based on the good practices and innovative models promoting resource integration, community empowerment and enhanced people's participation, was officially approved by the Prime Minister. 3) 3-Good progress. MDP Master Plan approved by the Prime Minister, with actions to address multidimensional needs of the poor. MDP approach is used by the Government in measuring poverty and designing relevant policies/regulations.

1) 16 targeted programs consolidated into 2 major national targeted programs (NTPs) for new rural development and poverty reduction. Government Decree 116 on 18 Jul 2016, replacing 3 education support policies. Importantly, UNDP enabled the issuance of the Govt’s MDG accelerated targets and action plan for Ethnic Minority (MAP-EM). The Viet Nam’s MDG acceleration targets is the first in the world attempt to go beyond addressing the unfinished MDGs at the national averages to addressing the unfinished MDGs among specific population groups. This contributed to the recognition of EM groups’ lagging behind national MDG progress as a national priority and directed two major NTPs to focus on the poorest EM communities. 2) 3-Good progress. The two NTPs on sustainable poverty reduction and new rural development approved in 2016, focusing on supporting ethnic minorities and extreme poor people. 03 implementing guidelines of the two NTPs developed and approved. 04 handbooks and 01 training curriculum for effective NTPs implementation developed. 3) 3-Good progress. The Government adopted multi-dimensional poverty (MDP) approach under the Prime Minister’s Decision No.1614/QĐ-Ttg. This MDP Master plan guides the national poverty reduction programming and targeting for 2016-2020. MDP approach is used by the Government in measuring poverty, designing and monitoring relevant policies/regulations

1) Number of accompanying Decrees and legal documents developed and issued to support the promulgation of the Disaster Risk Management Law 2) Number of disaster risk reduction (DRR) and climate change adaptation (CCA) policies, strategies and legislation revised to: - Embrace and keep track of changing dynamics of DRR, CCA and CC impacts; - Integrate gender equity and differing needs of vulnerable groups 3) Improvement of technical and functional capacity of Central Committee for Flood and Storm Control (CCFSC) and provincial stakeholders, measured by: - Number of direct beneficiaries of capacity building activities. - The increasing of overall capacity scorecard points (to be indicated in the Capacity Assessment Report by end of 2016). 4) Number of targeted vulnerable communes/wards have CBDRM plan of action developed under the CBDRM Programme 5) Number of “building blocks” for the CBDRM programme approved and disseminated

comment.narrative: 1) Zero. By end of 2011, Version 3 of the Disaster Risk Management (DRM) Law was circulated to Ministries and for public consultation. A first draft of the accompanying Decree was produced 2) Zero. The existing overall disaster risk reduction (DRR) and climate change adaptation (CCA) framework, though comprehensive, not yet reflecting the national, regional and international context and impacts of climate change, neither integrating gender equity and needs of vulnerable groups 3) Overall capacity scorecard of CCFSC was 2.2 points out of 5 points (2013) 4) None. 5) None. “Building blocks” are in the final stage of development, not yet rolled out.

1) No additional legal document, but interim target is: at least 01 study to provide inputs for initiating and sustaining a financial mechanism for DRM Law (specifically the Decree on Disaster Prevention Fund). 2) All relevant key technical papers initiated in 2015 address changing dynamics of DRR, CCA, CC impacts, and reflect gender equity and needs of vulnerable groups. 3) At least 300 CCFSC officials have improved knowledge on: - Damage and Need assessment; - Risk assessment; - Extreme flood and super-storm risk management 4) At least 250 new communes have their local CBDRM plan of actions developed 5) Development of an additional “building block” for the CBDRM programme financing reviewed (for future re - approval in 2016)

1) No additional legal document, but very good progress: - The initial analysis of CBDRM financing conducted and presented at mid-term review. - A study on sustainable funding strategy for DRM in line with the Law under draft and expected to be finalized in 2016. 2) Completed: - Draft Action Plan developed in partnership with World Bank - The draft Action Plan to implement the National Strategy on DRM. 3) 320 CCFSC staff (34% are women) have improved knowledge and skills on: - Damage and Need assessment; - Risk assessment; - Extreme flood and super-storm risk management 4) More than 250 (estimated 270) communes developed CBDRM plan of actions and conduct activities according to developed plans under the 1002 Programme. 5) Supported development of a Circular on CBDRM implementation expected to be approved in early 2016. Foundation study for the development of the additional “building block” under draft, however completion of building block may be delayed due to changes in Government systems. In total however 6/7 building blocks are now in place.

1) No additional legal document; but 01 review on DRR financing, including for CBDRM financing;
2) 03 DRR and CCA policies, strategies and legislation revised, including: - 01 guideline on integrating DRR and CCA into SEDP - 01 guidelines and 02 good practice reports on gender equity and promoting CBDRM guidelines for ethnic groups (Thai, Muong) 3) Improved technical and functional capacity of Central Committee for Flood and Storm Control (CCFSC) and provincial stakeholders, measured by: - At least 1,000 direct beneficiaries of capacity building activities. - Overall capacity scorecard points (to be indicated in the Capacity Assessment Report by end of 2016). 4) No target for 2016 5) 7/7 “building blocks” for the CBDRM programme approved and disseminated; the CBDRM will be reviewed and revised for Gov’s approval

1) No additional legal document; but 01 review completed on DRR financing, including for CBDRM financing mechanism from 2016-2025; 2) 03 DRR and CCA policies, strategies and legislation revised and approved by MPI/MARD, including: - 01 guideline on integrating DRR into SEDP approved by MPI in mid 2016 - 01 guidelines on mainstreaming gender in CDBRM, and 02 good practice reports on gender equity and promoting CBDRM guidelines for ethnic groups (Thai, Muong)
3) Improved of technical and functional capacity of Central Committee for Flood and Storm Control (CCFSC) and provincial stakeholders, measured by: - More than 1,000 direct beneficiaries of capacity building activities. - The overall capacity scorecard points are not yet availalbe. (This will be updated as soon as the data are available.) 4) n/a 5) 7/7 “building blocks” for the CBDRM programme approved and disseminated; All the building blocks were shared to provinces via e-learning platform by Disaster Management Center under WRD/MARD; the national programme on CBDRM were reviewed and revised for Gov’s approval with extension until 2030.

title.narrative: Support to multi-dimensional poverty reduction in urban

description.narrative: Support to multi-dimensional poverty reduction in urban areas.
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
number of additional females benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional males benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional people benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
Support to multi-dimensional poverty reduction in urban settings.
seat of a first-order administrative division
policy, planning and administration

1) Availability of multi-dimensional poverty (MDP) measures and level of institutionalization of the measures in Ho Chi Minh city (HCMC) 2) Availability of multi-dimensional and in-depth analyses on poverty status for evidence-based and participatory policy making 3) Number of evidence-based and participatory policies developed/revised/improved to address multi-dimensional poor and to ensure equal access to services 4) The availability of new and creative tools to address urban poverty following multi-dimensional approach. 5) The extent to which HCMC’s experience is shared with and applied by other provinces

comment.narrative: 1) Multi-dimensional poverty measures do not exist in Ho Chi Minh city (HCMC). Poverty status is monitored based on a monetary approach 2) There is a lack of multi-dimensional and in-depth analyses on poverty status for evidence-based and participatory policy making 3) Very few evidence-based and participatory policies that address multi-dimensional poverty, despite the fact that HCMC population is still suffering from many deficiencies, such as social security, housing, health care, and education, etc. 4) No tools specifically address urban poverty following multi-dimensional approach. 5) No province being shared or applying the same methodologies and tools, though MOLISA at the central level plans to develop action plans for implementing the Government’s Resolution 80B on poverty reduction following the multi-dimensional approach.

1) MDP measures, data collection procedure for monitoring, listing and targeting finalized and institutionalized 2) Consolidated report on 2013 MDP Pilot completed and shared with wide stakeholders; Research report on actual situation on urbanization and urban management in Viet Nam and in HCMC, suggesting options and actions for improvement 3) Two groups of policy developed based on the MDP approach: (i) Poverty reduction policies reviewed, developed and piloted in a number of HCMC’s localities, tailored to specific needs of prioritized groups, integrated into SEDPs and sectoral plans, and well-coordinated and monitored by different stakeholders; and (ii) HCMC's 2016-2020 Sustainable Poverty Reduction Programme 4) Policy pilots implemented, providing experience and recommendations for scaling up; MDP indicators and non-registered migrants included into VHLSS for MDP monitoring; Prioritized groups for poverty reduction identified 5) HCMC’s MDP progress and experience widely shared and consulted with central and local policy makers, researchers, etc. through various advocacy and media events, workshops for sharing experience, identifying areas for cooperation, planning future roadmap with other provinces

1) MDP measures, data collection procedure for monitoring, listing and targeting officially approved by HCMC People's Council for application in HCMC's 2016-2020 Sustainable Poverty Reduction Programme 2) Consolidated report on 2013 MDP Pilot, Urban Poverty Report 2012, and 4 working papers on MDP analysis, policy suggestions, and data collection models completed and shared with wide stakeholders; 3) HCMC's 2016-2020 Sustainable Poverty Reduction Programme developed with the official application of MDP approach and method. A relevant detailed policy framework is being developed and tailored to address specific deprivations of prioritized groups, integrated into SEDPs and sectoral plans, and well-coordinated and monitored by different stakeholders. 4) A number of policy interventions and coordination improvements implemented, providing experience and recommendations for developing the detailed policy framework for HCMC's new sustainable poverty reduction programme in 2016-2020; MDP indicators and non-registered migrants included into VHLSS for MDP monitoring; 5 prioritized groups for poverty reduction have been officially identified for relevant supports. 5) A "South-South Exchange Workshop on addressing MDP and improving Service Delivery" co-organized by UNDP Viet Nam (in coordination with UNDP BRH) and HCMC to share and exchange HCMC experience with 6 countries and OPHI. HCMC’s MDP progress and experience also widely shared and consulted with central and local policy makers, researchers, etc. through various advocacy and media events, workshops for sharing experience, identifying areas for cooperation, planning future roadmap with other provinces (Da Nang, Vung Tau, KonTum, etc.).

1) MDP measures built in official design of (i) Vietnam Household Living Standard Survey (VHLSS) 2016 design in Ho Chi Minh City for representative and comprehensive data for MDP monitoring purpose and (ii) HCMC 2016 Poor Listing for MDP targeting purpose. 2) Baseline analytical report on results of 2016 Poor Listing Survey developed; Policy proposal for MDP reduction in 2016-2020 developed. 3) Two action plans for rolling out HCMC Sustainable Poverty Reduction Program 2016-2020 developed for one pilot district and one pilot commune. 4) HCMC multidimensional poverty hub established for addressing MDP in HCMC and MDP knowledge exchange among domestic/foreign cities. 5) Materials, knowledge of multidimensional poverty developed, improved and shared widely within HCMC and other cities.

1) Official design and data collection of 2016 VHLSS in HCMC consisted of MDP indicators, whose data is expected in early 2017 for MDP monitoring; MDP measures fully institutionalized in HCMC 2016 Poor Listing Survey which provided data for identifying MDP households. 2) Baseline analytical report on results of 2016 Poor Listing Survey developed providing MDP scope in HCMC; Policy proposal for MDP reduction in 2016-2020 submitted for HCMC People’s Committee’s approval. 3) Two action plans for rolling out HCMC Sustainable Poverty Reduction Program 2016-2020 developed for one pilot district and one pilot commune and used as examples for other districts and communes to replicate; 4) HCMC multidimensional poverty hub established and based in HCMC as the first phase of Viet Nam strategic roadmap to form a regional hub for exchanging and enhancing MDP knowledge and innovative practices/models. 5) A MDP manual and a video clip introducing HCMC MDP listing process developed, shared widely (e.g. on websites, media), and used as training materials for different stakeholders at various levels; Knowledge and experiences in multidimensional poverty shared and exchanged with Da Nang authorities through a workshop in Da Nang.

comment.narrative: 1.1 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a staff recruitment process based on merit and competencies. Current staff recruitment process is not based on competencies but mainly relies on diplomas, and certificates. 1.2 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a result-based staff performance appraisal system. A set of indicators and criteria to assess work performance of civil servants are being developed. 1.3 Zero civil servant use the staff performance appraisal system, which has not been made available at the beginning of the project. 1.4 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a mechanism for result-based remuneration for civil servants. Remuneration policies for civil servants are not based on merits but rather on performance-unrelated diplomas and seniority. 1.5 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a training programme specialized for different categories of civil servants. Civil servant structure is not available, without job description for each position. Education and training provided to civil servants is not based on job positions’ requirements. 1.6 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a modern staff management information system (including staff recruitment, performance appraisal, training, etc.). Current staff management information system needs to be upgraded towards online, and integrated with new modules such as staff recruitment, performance appraisal, training… 2.1 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a specialized and independent unit and standard tools for measuring the quality of public administrative services delivered to citizens and organizations. 2.2 Zero online feedbacks by citizens and organizations on quality of public administrative services delivery.

1. 01 guideline for provincial REDD+ action plan development is finalised and adopted by Gov. 2. 01 decision of Gov. approving the proposal for National REDD+ fund establishment 3. 14 Site REDD+ action plans 4. 14000 people benefiting from site activities (of which 51% are female) 5. 01 design proposal for benefit sharing is proposed 6. 01 proposal for the development of GRM of REDD+ is submitted for consultation with stakeholders 7. 0 Safeguards Information System created to monitor impacts of - REDD+ interventions on Safeguards

1) 01 guideline. The final version of the decision regulating Provincial REDD+ Action Plan development guideline is ready for MARD's Minister to sign on. 2) 01 decision. The proposal on National REDD+ fund has been fianlized and waiting for signature of MARD's minister. 3) 10 site REDD+ action plans approved and under implementation while the action plans for the other 8 sites are under preparation or waiting for approval. 4) 37,752 people (51% are female) are benefiting from site activities 5) 01 proposal on "benefit sharing system-BDS/IAS" design adopted by Govt by a decision for piloting within 6 provinces under UN-REDD programme. Lessons from this pilot will inform the design of national features on BDS/IAS later on. 6) 01 proposal. The 2nd draft of : Grievance Redness Mechanisms (GRMs) report submitted to Viet Nam REDD+ office for further consultation with all related stakeholders. 7) 0 Safeguards Information System created, but selection of a consultancy firm who provide service for SIS development completed, and consultants started working from Dec. 2015

1) 01 National REDD+ Action Programme (NRAP) is revised in accordance with UNFCCC's related provisions and international good practices. 2) No target for 2016 3) 17 Site REDD+ plans are approved and implemented. 4) About 200,000 people (51% are female) benefit from site activities 5) Participatory Governance Assessment starts its replication into 4 provinces. 6) 02 PRAPs - Provincial REDD+ Action Plans of Lao Cai and Binh Thuan are formulated and put under implementation 7) 1 safeguards Information System created monitor impacts of - REDD+ interventions on Safeguards

1) The revised NRAP is submitted to Gov. office for final approval fo PM in December 2016. This is rated "good" quality by the independent review of the Programme for 2016. 2) Not applicable, as no target was set for 2016 3) 17 Site REDD+ Plans approved and agreements on funding have been signed off. Implementation started from quarter III and will last for 2 years. 4) About 331,000 people (51% are women) are benefiting from site activities from 2016 until 2018 5) PGA are under replication in 4 provinces including Lam Dong, Lao Cai, Ca Mau and Ha Tinh and led by Forest Protection Department (VNFOREST) 6) 02 PRAPs of Lao Cai and Binh Thuan have been approved in April 2016 and under implementation 7) SIS framework finalized by December 2016

capital of a political entity
Human rights affairs

1) Level of awareness and capacity of the Government officers in human rights treaty reporting, specifically in relation to the UPR, and selected human rights treaties (1 - very poor; 2 - relatively good; 3 - good; 4 - very good). 2) The extent to which treaty reporting's process and coordination is improved (1 - very poor; 2 - relatively good; 3 - good; 4 - very good). 3) Number of policy-oriented research commissioned to inform the executive in human rights reporting and policy development.

comment.narrative: 1) 1-very poor. Viet Nam is increasingly engaging with human rights mechanisms but the level of awareness and capacity on HR reporting is very poor. 2) 1-very poor. Coordinated and high quality human rights reporting as well as generating human rights data and information is still a big challenge inhibiting the development and implementation of targeted human rights policies in VN; the UPR process is still relatively new and being improved, guidance is needed on how to effectively compile and present the UPR report; Viet Nam is considering ratification of other core human rights treaties 3) Very few policy-oriented research in human rights. Human rights research is very ad hoc and does not focus on topics that are vital for the development of key government human rights policies; access to research products is still limited mostly to research institutions, uncoordinated and not linked to or providing reference for government agencies.

1) 3-Good level of awareness and capacity of Government officers to be achieved, through continued support with focus on implementation of UPR Action Plan, and CRPD and CAT reporting. 2) 3-Good level of treaty reporting's process and coordination, through support to establish an inter-ministerial reporting coordination group for data collection and monitoring. 3) One research on CRPD statistical gap to be conducted for recommendations to greater compliance in CRPD reporting.

1) 3-Good. Increased awareness of policy offers on CAT obligations and their implications to behavior changes and practices. Increased awareness of state officers across Government agencies on UPR commitments and the follow-up Action Plan. 2) 3-Good. CAT and CRPD data gap analysis has started and will be continued in 2016. Primary meeting of an inter-ministerial coordination group for human rights was organized. The UPR Action Plan approved by Prime Minister as results of cross-agency coordination led by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. 3) Research on CRPD statistical gap is commissioned, results will be published in 2016.

1) 3-Good level of awareness and capacity of Government officers to be achieved, through continued support with focus on implementation of UPR Action Plan, and CRPD and CAT reporting. 2) 3-Good level of treaty reporting's process and coordination, specifically through: joint efforts to advocate for human rights on the occasion of the International Human Rights Day (Dec. 2016) 3) Comparative study to identify CRPD statistical gap and recommendations for a set of CRPD indicators for CRPF reporting and data collection. Support to MPS for identifying CAT data gap and recommending a set of CAT indicators for reporting, data collection and monitoring.

1) 3-Good. Increased awareness of policy offers on CAT obligations and their implications to behavior changes and practices. Increased awareness of state officers across Government agencies on CRPD obligations, the National Action Plan for CRPD implementation, and their implications to behavivor changes and practices. 2) 3-Good. Joint activity between MOFA and other line ministries, UNDP and other development partners to advocate for equal rights and non-discrimination to LGBT people organized on the occasion of HRs day in Viet Nam. 3) 2 policy researches - CAT and CRPD data gap analysis - completed with concrete findings and recommendations for improvement on data collection and statistical system improvements. CRPD indicators are consulted with MOLISA and awaited for internal endorsement for data collection and reporting. CAT indicators are consulted with the MPS and be used for internal consultation in preparation for the CAT initial report.

description.narrative: 1) Number of strategic leaders trained with the revised gender-sensitive curriculum at the Ho Chi Minh Political Academy (HCMA). 2) Number of female officials participated in Women’s Leadership Program that was developed and institutionalized in HCMA. 3) Representation of women in Party Committees, National Assembly and People’s Councils 4) Number of female officers in the public sector having access to training courses on soft skills and participate in a mentoring programme. 5) Availability of the human resource procedures that promote women’s participation in leadership positions 6) Number of female officers who have access to the research grant program 7) Number of draft laws that have gender analysis conducted and fed to national law drafting team and National Assembly members 8) The extent to which university curriculum is gender sensitive (Scale: 0-not at all; 1-very litte; 2-little; 3-significant; 4-very significant)

comment.narrative: 1) 0. Existing training programs at the HCMA, its sub academies, and 63 provincial political schools are gender blind. 2) 0. Women in the public sector have limited access to professional leadership training programs run by government institutions. Few women civil servants receive training in leadership or management skills 3) For the 2011-2016 term, the percentage of women is 9% for the Central Committee of the Communist Party, 24.4% for the National Assembly, and less than 28% for the People’s Councils at all levels. 4) Women in the public sector have limited access to professional leadership training programs run by government institutions. 5) No availability. The current hiring, promotion and selection for training process in the civil service have not met the targets of the Strategy on Gender Equality. 6) 43 female officers were awarded research grants since 2009. However, the quality of their research and their understanding of gender mainstreaming still varies. 7) 0 law 8) 0-not at all. Most of university curriculum used in Viet Nam are gender blind.

1) 100 strategic leaders trained with this revised gender-sensitive curriculum. 2) The Women's Leadership Program finalized and 40 trainers benefited from the TOT training. 3) No specific target, as the elections will not take place until 2016. Interim targets are: At least 800 potential candidates for National Assembly and People's Council trained on leadership skills; At least 80 trainers trained; The Leadership Training Manual developed and disseminated to 63 provinces and widely used; An e-learning course developed and posted on internet for free access of potential candidates. 4) At least 250 female officers in the public sector participated in UNDP-supported training on leadership skills. 5) At least 120 people being trained on mainstreaming gender into HR practices. 6) No target for 2015 7) At least 1 draft law (Law on Organisation of Government) that has gender analysis conducted and fed to national law drafting team and National Assembly members 8) 2-little, through training for lecturers on gender mainstreaming in curriculum.

1) 100 strategic leaders being trained about gender equality, international experiences in gender equality with (this revised gender-sensitive curriculum) 2.)The Women's Leadership Program finalized and 40 trainers benefited from the TOT training 3) No specific result, as the elections will not take place until 2016. Key interim results are: 980 potential candidates for National Assembly and People's Council trained to have a systematic knowledge and leadership skills which are necessary for the election; At least 80 trainers trained and then provided training for potential candidates on leadership skills; The Leadership Training Manual developed and disseminated to 63 provinces and widely used by potential candidates; An e-learning course developed and posted on internet for free access of potential candidates. 4) 250 female officers in the public sector participated in UNDP-supported training on leadership skills. 5) 120 people trained on mainstreaming gender into HR practices. correct 6) N/A, as no target was set for 2015. 7) 2 draft law (Law on Organisation of Government and Law on Election) that has gender analysis conducted and fed to national law drafting team and National Assembly members 8) 2-little. 50 university lecturers trained on gender mainstreaming in the training curriculum.

comment.narrative: 1. Baseline (2010): - A number of wetlands inventories and classification systems exist, which need to be consolidated, rationalised and updated. - Decree 109 on the Conservation Sustainable Development of Wetlands (2003) needs better alignment with Biodiversity Law (2008) - The first Wetlands Action Plan period has come to an end in 2010. 2. Baseline (2010): 21% (measured by the Capaciy Development Scorecard) 3. Baseline (2010): No comprehensive (evidence-based) valuation of the ecosystem services exists

1. Three changes observed in major wetlands-related policies, laws and plans, including: - The wetland classification system revision and update drafted. - Survey on existing inventories of wetland in Vietnam for development of the list of important wetlands and mapping conducted - A proposal for new Decree on wetland management in Vietnam developed and submited to the Government for inclusion into the policy revision agenda. 2. Capacity building programme developed: - Training needs assessment on wetland management capacity conducted - Training curriculum development started - Office/training equipment provided - Proposal for National Wetland Working Group and Local Wetland Working Group operation drafted for wide stakeholder consultation 3. Preparation for the development of monetary and non-monetary valuation of ecosystem services completed, including a draft of ecosystem services assessment and valuation report in two pilot provinces and a communication strategy

description.narrative: Rapid Impact and Needs Assessment to address Existing Data Gaps Conducted
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1) Availability of relevant data, assessment on drought impacts in affected areas
2) Availability of the final draft Response and Recovery Plan focusing on the three impacted regions of the Mekong, South Central and Central Highlands of Viet Nam
3) The enhancement of UN DRMT capacity to lead the coordination (Scale: 0-no improvement yet; 1-little improvement; 2-significant improvement; 3-very significant improvement)

comment.narrative:
1) The current inter-agenciy rapid assessment mission can only provide very basic information on 6 of 12 highly impacted provinces
2) An effective and targeted response mechanism and recovery action plan are being developed
3) 1-little improvement, though UNDRMT had to lead and manage relief and recovery activities in the absence of a cluster system

1) An assessment report for early recovery in Ben Tre, and mapping of drought impacted areas
2) Multi-stakeholder efforts in supporting the Government to develop a response and recovery plan for impacted regions; Data and information collected are used during consultations to ensure the response and recovery plan is evidenced and need based.
3) 2-significant improvement: UNDRMT is able to facilitate RCO with necessary ME activities, travels and selective consultancy to enhance the leading and the coordinating role of RCO in mobilising and coordinating UNDRMT activities, managing and sharing information, utilising UN support to the national El Nino efforts

1) 1 analysis report on Viet Nam Drought and Saltwater Intrusion: Transitioning from Emergency to Recovery, with policy implications on recovery priorities and forward looking perspectives
2) (i) a recovery planning workshop with MARD and 18 provinces organised; (ii) partially finanical support to MARD International Support Group plenary meeting on International Cooperation for a sustainable agriculture adaptable to climate change and weather extremes; and (iii) Response and Recovery Plan consulted, finalised and launched
3) 2-significant improvement of UNDRMT capacity through (i) 2 joint monitoring visits to Ca Mau and Gia Lai conducted; (ii) technical consultant to support to coordinating role of RCO and UNDRMT activities; (iii) Plan materials developed, well designed and distributed.
